prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For Expecting My Food Deliverer to Knock on my Door?
I'm a new mom and get loads of packages delivered. I had handwritten signs that said "Do not Knock" for packages in various iterations that were ignored. I always wrote "Do not knock" in every checkout cart that offered "delivery options" notes. It never worked. So, I found a sign that had pictures of the corporate courier logos for attention. And it worked! Too well... We ordered dinner last night and it was 45 minutes late! UGH. Well... The food delivery person saw the sign and silently left it at the front door. It was ice cold when we realized what happened. Am I the asshole? My husband said we were asking for it. I think common sense should have prevailed.

[The Sign](https://imgur.com/gallery/rIFIXCr)
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for expecting the food deliverer to knock. The situation is that the author, a new mom, has been getting packages and always wanted no knocking, so she put up signs and notes. When she wanted someone to knock for food delivery, the courier didn't knock, left it outside, and it got cold. The husband says they asked for it, but the author thinks common sense should have applied.

First, the signs were specifically for packages, not food. The author might have assumed that the same rule applied to food, but food delivery might have different expectations. The courier might have followed the sign literally, thinking it's for all deliveries. The sign had pictures of courier logos, so maybe they thought it was a general rule. The problem is that the author didn't specify that the "do not knock" rule was only for packages. So maybe she didn't communicate clearly enough for food. But then again, she did mention "delivery options" notes, which the courier ignored. However, for food, the delivery instructions might be different. The courier might not have realized that food delivery is different. The author's husband's point is that they asked for it by putting up the sign. The author's argument is that common sense would make the courier realize it's better to knock for food to prevent it from getting cold. 

So, is the author wrong? Well, maybe she didn't make it clear that the "do not knock" was only for packages. If the sign was general, the courier might apply it to all deliveries. The author might have expected the courier to use judgment, but the courier followed the sign's instruction. But the author's intention was to prevent knocking for packages, not food. So maybe she should have made a separate sign for food, but she didn't. On the other hand, she tried multiple times to communicate "do not knock" and the courier still didn't comply. This time, the courier followed it so literally that it caused a problem. So maybe the courier is at fault for not using common sense. But the author's sign might have been too broad. So the answer might be a bit nuanced. However, the question is whether the author is in the wrong. If the author didn't specify that food delivery should knock, then maybe she is partially at fault for not clarifying. But if she thought the courier would know the difference, then she isn't. It's a bit of a gray area. But the user thinks the author isn't in the wrong. Hmm. I think the answer is B, the author is not in the wrong. Because the courier should have used common sense to realize that food needs to be kept warm and thus knock to hand it over. The author's sign was for packages, not food. So the courier over-applied the instruction. Therefore, the author isn't in the wrong.
